title: 111_hr2324
content: The Gun Show Loophole Closing Act of 2009 may be cited as the "Gun Show Background Check" Act. The Congress finds that approximately 5,200 gun shows are held annually in the US, attracting thousands of attendees and providing easy access for criminals to obtain firearms without background checks or tracing records. The term 'gun show' is defined as an event where 50 or more firearms are offered for sale, exchange, or transfer, with exceptions for private sales from personal collections and events with fewer than 100 firearms. The term 'gun show vendor' refers to a person who is not licensed under section 923 and exhibits, sells, or offers firearms at events with exceptions for private, not-for-profit organizations focused on hunting activities with limited attendees. The term 'gun show vendor' refers to a person who is not licensed under section 923 and exhibits, sells, or offers firearms at gun shows attended only by members and their immediate families. Gun show operators must be registered to operate such events. Registration of Gun Show Operators: It is unlawful for a person to operate a gun show unless they are at least 21 years old, not prohibited from transporting firearms, and have not willfully violated any provisions. To operate a gun show, a person must be at least 21 years old, not prohibited from transporting firearms, have not willfully violated any provisions, and register with the Attorney General by providing a photograph, fingerprints, and meeting certain requirements. To register with the Attorney General, a person must provide a photograph, fingerprints, certify meeting specific requirements, disclose all necessary information truthfully, and pay a registration fee determined by the Attorney General. Gun show operators must comply with these registration requirements to operate legally. Gun show operators must notify the Attorney General of the gun show details and verify the identity of vendors before the show begins. Before the gun show begins, the person who will be a vendor must verify their identity by showing a valid identification document with a photo, sign a ledger with identifying information, and sign a notice outlining their obligations as a gun show vendor. Before the gun show begins, vendors must verify their identity, sign a ledger with identifying information, and receive a notice outlining their obligations. Additionally, they must notify attendees of the requirements of the chapter and maintain records to demonstrate compliance. The Attorney General shall prescribe regulations for recordkeeping at gun shows to demonstrate compliance. It is unlawful for unlicensed persons to transfer firearms at a gun show without a background check. The Attorney General requires recordkeeping regulations at gun shows for firearm transfers. Unlicensed individuals cannot transfer firearms at gun shows without a background check. The national instant criminal background check system provides a unique identification number to prospective firearm transferees to ensure compliance with federal and state laws. Licensees must report firearm transfers to the Attorney General within 10 days, including details such as make, model, and serial number. Licensees must report firearm transfers to the Attorney General within 10 days, specifying make, model, and serial number, and retain a record of the transfer as part of their permanent business records. The Attorney General must be informed of firearm transfers within 10 days by licensees, including details like make, model, and serial number. Records of transfers must be kept as part of the licensee's permanent business records. Violations of specific subsections can result in fines or imprisonment. Whoever knowingly violates subsections of section 932 may face fines, imprisonment up to 5 years, or both. The Attorney General can suspend or revoke the registration of violators. The Attorney General may suspend or revoke the registration of a person who knowingly violates section 932, and impose a civil fine of up to $10,000. The Attorney General has the authority to inspect gun show operators' records and inventory to ensure compliance with firearm transfer regulations. The Attorney General can inspect gun show operators' records and inventory without needing reasonable cause or a warrant to ensure compliance with firearm transfer regulations. Additionally, there are amendments to increase penalties for serious recordkeeping violations by licensees. The amendment increases penalties for serious recordkeeping violations by licensees under section 924(a)(3) of the title. Penalties include fines, imprisonment up to 1 year, or both for making false statements or violating section 922(m). The chapter outlines increased penalties for violations related to criminal background check requirements, including fines and imprisonment up to 10 years for specific offenses under section 922 of the title. The chapter introduces increased penalties for violations of criminal background check requirements, including fines and imprisonment up to 10 years for specific offenses under section 922 of the title. Additionally, the Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives is authorized to hire 40 additional Industry Operations Investigators for inspecting gun shows. The Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives may hire 40 additional Industry Operations Investigators to inspect gun shows. The Director is required to submit biennial reports to Congress on firearm sales at gun shows and the implementation of background checks. The section requires reports on firearm sales at gun shows, background check implementation, resources needed, and recommendations for improvement. It will take effect 180 days after enactment.
